Comment: >House Republicans are trying to massively expand Donald Trump’s executive powers with a bill that is ostensibly about taxes and border security.  >The House Judiciary Committee released a draft bill Monday that would move antitrust enforcement away from the independent Federal Trade Commission into the Justice Department. The bill would also require congressional approval for all new regulations, giving Republicans greater power over virtually the entire federal government.  >Under the bill, federal agencies would have to submit portions of their rules to Congress, which would have to approve them within five years. If the rules aren’t approved, they would be gone, giving Republicans the ability to easily gut regulations they don’t like.

Comment: Because they are just as wicked as he is.   They are not decent people being coerced into bad things.  They are indecent people empowering other indecent people, counting on optimistic, decent, and forgiving people like you to carry water for them, using 'fear' as a convenient excuse, while protecting and celebrating acts of terrorism against the general federal workforce and political boogeymen of their own propaganda.   Even John McCain, supposedly decent person,  unleashed Sarah Palin on the country (directly leading to Trump).   When a woman at one of his rallies called Obama a "Muslim" as a slur, John McCain met her halfway "He's not a Muslim;  He's a decent man."  He didn't correct the record by clarifying Obama's religion by citing well known public events (the Reverend Wright 'scandal.')  He didn't admonish her bigotry against Muslims.   He tried to "defend" Obama by contrasting being Muslim (false allegation) with another (decent man).     There is a faustian rot at the core of being a Republican which makes everyone hold their tongue for the sake of not suffering a political setback.  Nor do they attempt to correct the behavior of the lowest common denominator.   They'd rather lean into self-destructive behavior if it can benefit them in the short term, pledging to, at some indeterminate point in the future, adjust course when they deem it a step too far, not able to follow any inductive reasoning or recursive train of thought to see the truth that they're already setting themselves up for failure.   It is not fear, it is a fundamental lack of core principles and religious devotion to the conservative cause .   There is no moral truth too sacred to debase
